publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-1564 Mr Brian Monteith: Smoking in Pubs-That the Parliament believes that the people best placed to know how to run their pubs and to assess how to accommodate and meet their customers' needs most appropriately are the local landlords; believes that a ban on smoking in pubs would be illiberal and would remove the right of millions of law-abiding people to enjoy a relaxing drink and smoke in their local pubs; believes that a smoking ban would have a seriously detrimental effect on the licensed trade; understands that many staff who work in pubs smoke themselves; notes that a number of smaller country pubs do not actually employ any staff at all; recognises that people considering working in pubs make that choice knowing that they may well encounter smoky atmospheres at work; further recognises that people going into pubs for social purposes make that same choice; believes that preventing people from smoking in pubs in order to protect those who work in pubs, who may be smokers themselves anyway, is inconsistent with, for example, allowing people to work down coal mines and with chemicals; believes that, if there is a demand for non-smoking pubs or pubs which have both smoking and non-smoking areas, the free market would deliver such establishments, and therefore totally rejects the idea of a ban on smoking in pubs, believing that it is the responsibility of pub landlords to decide what kind of establishment they wish to run, having due regard to their customers and staff. Supported by: Phil Gallie*, Mr Jamie McGrigor*, Murdo Fraser*, Alex Johnstone*
